page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: This D-Block includes all of Blacon, which is a suburb of Chester mainly providing a housing area for the city. With its high-rise flats, community centre, small shopping precincts and other typical modern ammenities, it surprises many that Blacon was in the Domesday Survey of 1086 (as Blachehol a farming area and fishery). Over 3kms of the England/North Wales border passes through the D-Block roughly following the old course of The River Dee. This land bordering the aptly names Sealand Road leading from Chester into Wales is mainly reclaimed land used for farming except for the thriving Sealand Industrial Estate. Two kms of tidal Dee waters, re-routed in 1735-6, flow within the D-Block, as well as about 2kms of the Shropshire Union Canal.
